bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Jefferson Randolph Kean, May 10, 1898

div1.p: Reed explains his tardiness in replying to Kean's letter, recounts having asked the Surgeon General, unsuccessfully, for a transfer, and suggests several alternatives for dealing with frustration. [Courtesy of The Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia Library]

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Jefferson Randolph Kean, May 10, 1898
div1.opener:
WAR DEPARTMENT,
SURGEON GENERAL'S OFFICE,
ARMY MEDICAL MUSEUM AND LIBRARY,
WASHINGTON.
May 10, 1898.
My Dear Doctor Kean;
div1.p:
I know
that you think, or should
think, that I have treated
you shabbily, but, my dear,
good Doctor, if you had
had as many irons in the
fire & as many young doc=
tors hanging to your coat-
tails, as I have had, you
would have been obliged
to first extricate your
said garments froms
the aforesaid clutches, be=
fore doing anything else!
I have interviewed the S.G.
& so has Dr Bache, but ,alas!
I fear that circumstances
of station and duty have put
you & myself in about the
same predicament! In other
words, my dear fellow, ifwe
are not “in it”! When,
more than four weeks
ago, I requested the Gen-
eral to approve my
assignment to Sampson's
squadron (for I didn't see
any fun ahead for a “land-
lubber,”) he positively refused.
When I then asked to be sent
to my dear old land of good
friends & mangoes, he said
“Nay” with equal emphasis!
When I spoke of your case,
he said, “Well, somebody must
be near Bosting, and I
don't see why Dr Kean,
won't do as well as any
body else”! There you have
it in a nutshell! Stay
in the land of wooden
Haws, my dear Doctor! ‘Tis
true they are not very
toothsome, but nevertheless
stay!!’ My only consolation
is to get outside of 2
ozy of Tarantula extract
every 15 minutes and then
cuss the murderous
Spaniards! Why don't
you have them make you
Chief Surgeon of the
Nutmeg troops, with the
rank of Lieutenant Col.?
I see that Pope, Hoff, Mans
& several other medicos have
had that honor thrust upon
them - Will you “take some-
thing” with me? My kindest
regards to your good lady
& a kiss for dear little Martha.
